{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2924633,"name":"Andy Mundell","username":"suPURDUEperAndy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/supurdueperandy/{size}/266209_2.png","created_at":"2021-01-17T21:42:47.405Z","cooked":"

I am looking at the WPILib example C++ code for a SwerveBot. I noticed that they programmed the drive motors with frc2::PIDController and the turn motors with frc::ProfiledPIDController

From what I understand the profiled PID creates a trapezoidal response for the acceleration in the turn motor, whereas the drive motor is a traditional PID. Is this understanding correct and what is the reasoning behind doing these two PIDs differently.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2021-01-17T21:42:47.405Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":471,"reads":265,"readers_count":264,"score":2408.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":390489,"topic_slug":"swerve-turn-motor-pid-question","display_username":"Andy Mundell","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36711,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-turn-motor-pid-question/390489/1","custom_user_title":"7457 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":2924642,"name":"Greg Billetdeaux","username":"GregBilletdeaux","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gregbilletdeaux/{size}/137999_2.png","created_at":"2021-01-17T22:04:36.958Z","cooked":"

Drive motors, you typically only care about getting up to speed and maintaining it. So a traditional PID controller makes sense. Azimuth motors (rotation), you are more concerned with moving from position A to position B. Trapezoidal motion profiling is, when tuned, the most controlled method of doing that. Controlled in the sense that you don’t oscillate, you don’t over-exert the motor, and is arguably the fastest path between those points.

Hello , but my turning motor can’t move . Is its kP too small ?

Does it turn if you just send it a straight value? Like if you forgo the PID for a moment, and just send it .75 or 1? If not, you’ve got an unrelated issue, probably mechanical or wiring.

Their swerve drive moves, and they can run characterization, so it seems like a software integration issue.

A question when using the Robot Characterization Programming
Hello , when l characterize the turning motor. It seems that the kP value is too small that the turning motor can’t even turn . Also , the feedforward seems to be bad because when l enable my robot. The turning motor seems to rotate fiercely and permenantly. l think that l may be puzzled with the Units per rotation using Radians. [image] How should l calculate it , or just use 2 * Math.PI?

They’ve been replying to every swerve-related thread they can find in the last week. Here’s a handful of them with more info:

The question about zeroOffset in swerve Programming
Our team is trying to use swerve. l use the Official WPILIB’s swerve example as my example . In the WPI’s example , there seems to be no zerooffset. But when l tune my swerve in the lab, l found that it is still necessary to set an zeroOffset. Or has WPI’s official lib contains this function, so how to use it ? Or, how can l reach this function , with WPI’s swerve methods? Any answer is appreciated.
Some questions about the WPI's official swerve code Programming
Hello , when l use the WPILIB’s official code , it seems that my swerve drive can’t drive normally. The swerve module can’t drive forward, it seems that it only rotate forward and back. My whole code is below : 2021Swerve.zip (32.6 MB) Any answer is appreciated!
Using WPILibJ (Java) Swerve Example - DIOJNI Error Programming
Hello , how do you use swerve module’s angle in the WPI Swerve code?
A question about Falcon 500's encoder Programming
Sorry to bother you again. If l wire an encoder to talon srx. And l want to use its analog input. It seems that l need to know which port Id it uses . Is the port id the same with the talosrx’s port id?
github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

The "angleOffset" in SwerveDrive

opened 02:28PM - 17 Aug 21 UTC
closed 05:31PM - 20 Sep 21 UTC
mendax1234
type: support

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.** A clear and …concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...] Well , when l use the SwerveBot example on my swerve drive., (l have already adjusted the encoders and motors according to my swerve drive) it seems that the angle of the swerve module is different. l have already searched for some imformation and studied other team's swerve code like 2910. l have found that the "angleOffset" (the angle which needs to be adjusted when the module's wheel is all set to one direction ). The "angleOffset" also needs to be added to the currentangle of each swerve in order to let every swerve module face the same direction during the drive or competition. However , it seems that the SwerveBot example or the SwerveControllerExample doesn't have any part of code to add the "angleOffset". **Describe the solution you'd like** A clear and concise description of what you want to happen. l am not sure of my solution. But l will put my whole code below. **Describe alternatives you've considered** A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered. It seems that there is no alternatives for it. **Additional context** Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. The whole code:
